site_name: SeaQuest Interactive Aquarium Fort Worth LLC

citations.narrative:
On June 30, 2024, a member of the public was bitten by the sloth named “Flash” during a public interaction session. This
incident was reported to the local animal control department, and a quarantine was issued for the animal. The facility
stated that “Flash” grabbed the public member’s arm, swiftly bit the arm, and immediately let go. The facility stated that
based on the superficial nature of the wound, they believed it was a test bite to determine the availability of food.
Additionally, on August 31, 2024, a member of the public was bitten by the Bengal cat named “Anubis” during a public
interaction session. This incident was reported to the local animal control department, and a quarantine was issued for the
animal. The facility stated that “Anubis” abruptly turned and gave a warning nip to the public member after the animal was
pet high on the neck.
Inadequate control or handling of animals during public interactions can lead to the injury of the public and the animals,
and animals involved in the injury of the public are at risk of quarantine and euthanasia, as required by county and state
mandates.
The facility must ensure that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
To be corrected from this date, September 19, 2024, forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On June 30, 2024, a member of the public was bitten by the sloth named “Flash” during a public interaction session. This 
incident was reported to the local animal control department, and a quarantine was issued for the animal. The facility 
stated that “Flash” grabbed the public member’s arm, swiftly bit the arm, and immediately let go. The facility stated that 
based on the superficial nature of the wound, they believed it was a test bite to determine the availability of food.  
 
Additionally, on August 31, 2024, a member of the public was bitten by the Bengal cat named “Anubis” during a public 
interaction session. This incident was reported to the local animal control department, and a quarantine was issued for the 
animal. The facility stated that “Anubis” abruptly turned and gave a warning nip to the public member after the animal was 
pet high on the neck. 
 
Inadequate control or handling of animals during public interactions can lead to the injury of the public and the animals, 
and animals involved in the injury of the public are at risk of quarantine and euthanasia, as required by county and state 
mandates.  
 
The facility must ensure that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. 
 
To be corrected from this date, September 19, 2024, forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
